alert.note: Alert for Wilkin (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks (Northeastern North Dakota and Northwestern Minnesota)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 10 at 8:39PM CDT until May 13 at 1:00PM CDT by NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Minnesota...North Dakota... Red River of the North at Drayton affecting Walsh, Marshall, Pembina and Kittson Counties. Red River of the North at Wahpeton affecting Richland and Wilkin Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Minnesota...North Dakota... Red River of the North at Oslo affecting Grand Forks, Polk, Marshall and Walsh Counties. South Branch Buffalo River at Sabin affecting Clay County. Buffalo River near Dilworth affecting Clay County. Sheyenne River Diversion at West Fargo affecting Cass County. Sheyenne River at Harwood affecting Cass County. Maple River near Mapleton (South of I-94) affecting Cass County. Red River of the North at Pembina affecting Pembina and Kittson Counties. Red River of the North at Fargo affecting Cass and Clay Counties. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM THURSDAY MORNING TO EARLY SATURDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Red River of the North at Wahpeton. * WHEN...From Thursday morning to early Saturday afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, MINOR FLOOD. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:30 PM CDT Wednesday the stage was 10.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late tomorrow morning to a crest of 11.1 feet early tomorrow afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage Friday morning. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Safety message - Turn around, don`t drown. Don`t travel through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
